channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Renewed Riots and Gunfire in Ukraine Shatter Brief Truce
item.description: Ukraine’s descent into a spiral of violence accelerated on Thursday, just hours after a truce had been declared, as protesters clashed with riot police officers to reclaim areas of Independence Square, the symbolic central plaza in the capital.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Resignations in Suspected Child Pornography Case Split Merkel’s Coalition
item.description: Two men have become embroiled in a scandal: a lawmaker named in the case and a cabinet minister who revealed privileged information about him.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Maurizio Gambarini/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sebastian Edathy quit as a Social Democratic lawmaker on Feb. 7. He has denied wrongdoing.

item.title: Pakistani Airstrikes Kill Suspected Militants in Tribal Areas
item.description: The overnight raids came as efforts to hold peace talks with Taliban insurgents sputtered.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: North and South Koreans Meet in Emotional Family Reunions
item.description: Relatives who had not seen each other in more than half a century gathered at a resort in North Korea as reunions resumed for the first time since 2010.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Deal Reached to Resume Expansion of Panama Canal
item.description: Work on the expansion was set to start again on Thursday after the builders and the canal authority agreed on a way to pay suppliers.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Paper Links Ukraine Strife to Rapid Political Reform
item.description: An editorial in the Communist Party’s Global Times warns that independence following the collapse of the Soviet Union set the stage for the deep-rooted economic and political tensions currently roiling Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Protesters hold gasoline bombs as they stand behind barricades during clashes with the police on Thursday in Kiev. The violence that has erupted in Ukraine is being held up as an example of the perils of loosening political controls.

item.title: India Ink: Politics Behind Move to Free Gandhi Assassination Plotters, Analysts Say
item.description: The Tamil Nadu chief minister’s decision to release seven men who planned the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi is seen as an example of a state trying to rouse popular sentiment before the May elections.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: Disillusionment in Libya Over Vote on Charter Assembly
item.description: Increasingly frustrated Libyans on Thursday will elect 60 lawmakers to write a new constitution after Parliament failed to appoint the charter-drafting body.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Tony Blair Emerges as Figure in Tabloid Hacking Case
item.description: According to an email read at trial, the former British prime minister told a major figure in the scandal, Rebekah Brooks, to “keep strong,” and offered to act as an “unofficial adviser.”
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Censors Have Kept Their Hands Off ‘House of Cards’
item.description: The absence of censorship for the Chinese broadcast of the series is somewhat surprising, and it may indicate a more relaxed approach toward the newer medium of online television show imports.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN and SHANSHAN WANG
item.media:credit: Nathaniel E. Bell/Netflix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kevin Spacey as the ruthless American politician Francis Underwood with Robin Wright as his wife, Claire.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Latest Attacks on Doctors Prompt New Call for Deterrent Measures
item.description: Attacks on doctors at Chinese hospitals have risen in recent years — this week there were two attacks in two days, one fatal, and medical representatives have called for harsher penalties.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The police stand guard last October outside a hospital in Wenling, Zhejiang Province, after hospital workers staged a protest against attacks on medical personnel.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Members Propose Resolution on Syrian Aid
item.description: Members of the United Nations Security Council put forth a draft resolution late Wednesday to try to force the warring parties to allow humanitarian aid.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: In Mexico Meeting, a Show of Friendship With Few Results on Immigration and Trade
item.description: At a summit meeting, President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts promised enduring cooperation, but the show of friendship did not mask the stress points.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Presidents Obama and Enrique Peña Nieto, center, with Prime Minister Stephen Harper on Wednesday.

item.title: Getting Stares on the Streets of Cambodia: Buses for the Masses
item.description: Phnom Penh is experimenting with a public transportation system, beginning with 10 buses, in a program underwritten by the Japanese government.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Luc Forsyth for The New York Times
item.media:description: A public bus stop in Phnom Penh last week.

item.title: Violence in Ukraine Creates Deepening Clash Between East and West
item.description: As Russia denounced what it called a coup by extremists, the United States and Europe threatened to impose sanctions on those responsible for the violence — and each side accused the other of interference.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Protesters on Wednesday burned documents after trying to take over a government office in Ternopil, Ukraine. The violence in the country has killed at least 25 people this week.

item.title: North Korea Arrests Christian Missionary From Australia
item.description: The arrest of John Short, 75, comes as North Korea continues to face pressure to release Kenneth Bae, an American missionary it has held for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Nationalistic Remarks From Japan Lead to Warnings of Chill With U.S.
item.description: Comments criticizing the United States by associates of Japan’s prime minister have furthered concerns that a rift is growing between the two governments.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: In Mexico, a Show of Friendship With Little Results on Immigration and Trade
item.description: At a summit meeting, President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts promised enduring cooperation, but the show of trilateral friendship did little to mask a series of stress points.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Presidents Obama and Enrique Peña Nieto, center, with Prime Minister Stephen Harper on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Leader Strains for Grip as Chaos Spreads
item.description: Opposition leaders confirmed overnight that a truce had been reached with the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, but it was uncertain that any pause in the conflict would hold.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters kept barricades burning on Wednesday in Kiev, Ukraine, to prevent riot police officers from storming Independence Square.

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Army Discloses Military Deaths
item.description: The army on Wednesday said that more than 100 soldiers had been killed by Taliban militants in the past five months, a rare admission of casualties.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pushing Back Against Government Surveillance
item.description: When the Beijing lawyer Xie Yanyi asked his government to tell him about its spying on citizens, he got a no-reply answer. But the problem is worldwide and needs to be solved worldwide, he said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Ministry of Public Security's response: "Not within the parameters of government information.’’

item.title: Finland 3, Russia 1: In Hockey Loss, Russian Pride Yields to Gloom
item.description: The men’s hockey team, which was put forward as the host country’s most important entry in the Winter Games, made a surprising early exit.
item.dc:creator: By KAREN CROUSE
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian hockey players lined up to shake hands after losing to Finland and being eliminated from the Olympic tournament.

item.title: World Briefing: Seychelles: 2 From U.S. Found Dead on Ship Made Famous in ‘Captain Phillips’
item.description: Two Americans providing antipiracy security on the Maersk Alabama, a ship made famous by the 2013 Hollywood film, were found dead on the vessel, a shipping group said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing : Libya: Justice Minister Details Plan for Compensation to Rape Victims
item.description: Women raped during the 2011 uprising that toppled Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi will be offered compensation, Libya’s justice minister, Salah al-Marghani, said on Wednesday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Athens Journal: Hard Times Leave Some Greek Car Owners With Nothing but Rust
item.description: Greeks have long had a love affair with cars, but lately, Greece has become a vast graveyard of abandoned automobiles, with motorists who can no longer afford to pay the taxes on their vehicles turning in piles of car plates.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Car plates are piled up at the central tax office in Athens, returned by motorists who could no longer afford to pay the taxes on their vehicles.
